chunks.en: How to effectively combat smoking in public places?
I have chronic pharyngitis and hate secondhand smoke.

My workplace is located in a high-end commercial and residential integrated office building, and in front of the toilets and fire escape doors on almost every floor, there are often some guys smoking alone or in groups.
The fire escape is closed and not ventilated. Because there are only two or three toilets on each floor, people inevitably use the fire escape to go to the toilet upstairs.
If it's just passing through the fire escape and smelling it a couple of times, that's fine, but the toilet is the most annoying place.
Each stall door has a 'No Smoking' sign, but that's it, it all depends on individual awareness.
After squatting in a stall, not only is my throat uncomfortable, but the smell of smoke all over my body is especially disgusting.

I called the mayor's hotline before to complain that the property management was doing nothing about it. The property management then called to verify and told me that they would sign agreements with all the companies on the relevant floors, so that the companies themselves would restrain their employees. If such behavior is discovered again, it would be directly reported to the fire department, etc.
But after all these operations, the situation has not improved at all, and I'm too lazy to call the mayor's hotline again.
I don't dislike people who smoke, but I extremely dislike smoking in public places.
I don't know what methods or experiences V users have in this regard, please share them, thank you.
@euclidhuang OP has chronic pharyngitis, which is important to him.
Doesn't he have the right to do this?

chunks.en: Run to Singapore, you can't smoke anywhere with a roof over your head, unless there's a sign saying you can, and you'll be fined so much you'll doubt your life if you violate it a few times.
As a non-smoker and extremely disgusted by smoke, I sympathize with OP. My current approach is: 1.

I found a relatively good company where my colleagues are relatively self-conscious. Although occasionally someone goes to the stairwell to smoke, it's rare. Basically, they all go to the trash can downstairs to smoke.

2. If someone smokes in a closed public area where I live, I will directly stop them, but I usually use a relatively gentle attitude. In fact, as long as the attitude is acceptable, neighbors will understand each other.
3. I usually only go to a few shopping malls where smoking in the toilets is strictly controlled, so there is basically no smoking in the toilets.
Anyway, on the one hand, I try my best to change things without causing conflict, and on the other hand, I avoid them as much as possible.
@euclidhuang Graves and neighbors slaughtering pigs are not illegal, but smoking in public places is illegal.
@worldhandsomeboy Agreed.
@euclidhuang #3 Self-reflection also needs a basic law.
There is a difference between neutral behavior and subjective malice/illegal behavior. I hope you think of this when you encounter neighbors making noise and disturbing the people.
It is recommended to carry an N95 mask with you in the domestic environment.
As a smoker, I also hate smoking in public places, and I hope all smokers disappear immediately ğŸ˜€
People who smoke while walking are the most disgusting. If they walk slowly, I usually pass them.
Some idiots smoke and walk fast, wishing everyone on the road would take a puff of their secondhand smoke.
@worldhandsomeboy #46 'Don't care at all', 'disgusting as hell'.
Really classic.
Indeed, there is nothing we can do except actively advocate and promote smoking bans in public places.
After all, moral bottom lines are not something you are born with.
I can only sincerely wish that your children, pregnant wife, and frail parents will meet people who blow secondhand smoke in their faces wherever they go.
Bear with it, be good.

The smoking rate among adult men in China is as high as 50%, and the penalties for smoking everywhere are extremely low. Toilets and fire escape corridors are the hardest hit areas. During the Spring Festival holiday, when eating in restaurants in small cities, there were people smoking in every room.
@euclidhuang I guess you are one of those smokers mentioned by OP
@bubble21 Seriously, N95 can't filter out the smell of smoke.
There's probably no solution. I hate people who smoke on the road the most, and when they smoke in front, I inhale secondhand smoke behind.
However, I inevitably have to walk to and from work. If I see someone smoking in front of me, I hold my breath and run past quickly.
I've been driving to work for the past six months, and I walk less, so the situation is much better /doge
In Japan, smoking in non-smoking public places is punishable by a maximum fine of 500,000 yen.
Smoking while walking on the street costs several thousand yen in fines, smoking while riding a bicycle costs a fine, and littering cigarette butts costs a fine.

In fact, if China ever sees catching smokers and fining them as a way to generate revenue, then it will be able to completely ban smoking in public areas (but thinking about it, many leaders also smoke...)
The biggest problem with this is the difficulty of obtaining evidence.
In Hangzhou, I called 12345 before, and the staff there asked me to control the smokers.
I was really stunned.

@RoyRao #36 It is reasonable to take a small portion of the tobacco tax to set up smoking areas; if there are smoking areas, but people still smoke in public places, then fines should be imposed to generate tax revenue.
@iyaozhen In Beijing, reporting only works for a while. Once the issue blows over, people smoke however they want, and the men's toilet is definitely the hardest hit area.
Stick a battery-powered smoke detector on the ceiling, it works wonders.

I also hate smoking, especially since my wife got pregnant. I hate those who smoke while walking even more; the whole road smells of smoke, and I have to trot ahead of them every time. The people who are smoking in the restaurants too, so many children are eating during the holidays, inhaling secondhand smoke to the fullest.
